conclusion: The gas is an ideal gas of constant mass, process goes from state A to B to C, temperature at state A is 27°C.
State A: p = 3 × 10³ Pa, V = 1 × 10⁻³ m³; State B: p = 2 × 10³ Pa, V = 2 × 10⁻³ m³; State C: p = 2 × 10³ Pa, V = 3 × 10⁻³ m³.
Convert temperature at state A to Kelvin: T_A = 27°C + 273 = 300 K.
For an ideal gas: PV = nRT, since mass is constant, n is constant, so PV/T = constant = nR.
Find the constant at state A: PV/T = (3 × 10³ Pa)(1 × 10⁻³ m³)/300 K = 10 Pa·m³/K.
Use the constant to find T_C: T_C = (P_C × V_C)/(PV/T)_constant = (2 × 10³ Pa)(3 × 10⁻³ m³)/(10 Pa·m³/K) = 600 K.
Convert temperature at state C back to Celsius: T_C = 600 - 273 = 327°C.
Final answer: The temperature of the gas in state C is 600 K or 327°C.
